body:
Contacts are the life-blood of any prosperous business. The more you know about them, the more effective you can be with your marketing activities - and the more successful your business will be.

In this page, you will learn what capabilities Kentico provides you for working with contacts.

You will learn about:

  • Why you should care about managing contacts and segmenting them into relevant groups.
  • How Kentico tracks website visitors.
  • Who contacts are and what information you can find in the Contact management application.
  • How you can segment your existing contacts into contact groups.
  • What contact information you can use to segment your contacts.

You will work on:

  • Contacts profiles in Contact management application.
  • Creating a dynamic contact group.
title: Introduction to contact management

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Why use Contact Management

So you've got a great website and you use web analytics to get aggregated data  on your online metrics. That's great, as web analytics helps you monitor website performance. But do you have the insight necessary to actually start improving your website's performance? Understanding your website visitors and their behavior will help you take the right actions. For this, we have contact management

Let's see how contact management can work for you. Let's say you're the owner of Nice Diced Ice, a construction company that builds igloos. Despite global warming, your website is visited by thousands of visitors looking for new homes. As soon as a new visitor arrives on your site, you want to start collecting as much information about them as possible. Though still anonymous, just the arrival gives you the visitor's traffic source, location, and more! As they take actions on your website, the system tracks the journey and logs which pages are visited and what's searched for, downloaded, watched, and so on. At some point this visitor fills in one of your online forms, so you know his name and email address.

As choosing a new place to live takes a long time, he returns to your site multiple times, sometimes using different browsers and even different devices. Your website can automatically track his visits and behavior across multiple channels, merging them into a single contact profile.

Each visitor and their information are then stored in Contact Management - your centralized hub for all details about all website visitors. Using this hub, you can get a 360-degree view of each visitor at a glance. You can use similar interests or characteristics to divide your contacts into groups and then improve their experiences by delivering content relevant to each group.

You can even tailor the content of your website or emails to each individual visitor. You can look at their activities and score contacts most likely to buy. You can create workflows to build relationships with contacts who aren't yet ready. And you'll get a clear idea of your ideal customer and their journey together with a better understanding of how to help them along it.

So you see, contact management means data and data means insights. Actively using contact management can help you: get deeper insight into visitors and their journeys, improve your management of contacts, and increase your efficiency across teams.

Take a look at your own contacts and see what you can learn.

body:
Every visitor of a Kentico-powered website (which is using online marketing features) is considered a contact. Kentico uses cookies to identify visitors and track their activities. To enable the tracking, visitors first need to provide the system with tracking consent. Once they agree, the system automatically gathers data about them based on their actions and inputs on the website.

Kentico recognizes two types of contacts - those who didn't provide the website with their email, and those who did.

  • Anonymous contacts represent visitors who agreed on the tracking but who haven't provided their email address. Kentico automatically creates their contact profiles and assigns value Anonymous + time the contact was created into the Last name contact field by default.
  • Contacts are the rest of the website's visitors who agree on the tracking. If the visitor makes a purchase, they become a customer in Kentico terms. When a contact or customer decides to register on the website, they become the website's registered users. Then, if the user is granted an Editor privilege level, they will also be able to sign in to the administration UI and (based on their permissions) change the content of the website.
title: Contacts in Kentico

body:
Kentico uses cookies to track visitor's activities on the website. A cookie is a small piece of data that is stored into your visitor's browser and allows the website to "remember" their actions and preferences over time. The information is then collected into Kentico administration and allow you to build your marketing activities. For example, the VisitorStatus cookie identifies whether your visitor is new or returning.

There are two main types of cookies which web applications use to track their visitors; session cookies and persistent cookies.

  • Session cookies are temporary and expire when your visitors close their browsers. Session cookies remember actions your visitors did during their browsing (= session) on your website and help improve the basic experience with the website. For example, on a multilingual site, one of the session cookies remembers the language choice of your visitors (or identifies it based on their browser settings) and makes sure the preferred culture stays the same across all the pages on the website until your visitor closes their browser.
  • Persistent cookies are stored on the visitors’ drives, and they remain there until they expire or until the user deletes them (e.g., when clearing browser history). Thanks to the persistent cookies, you can recognize your returning visitors and using their browsing history on your website, you can target your messaging accordingly and custom-tailor their website experience. Persistent cookies need to have an expiration date, and although there are no limitations to this, you should only expect them to be active for more than a few months. (Keep in mind that visitors can erase them anytime in their browsers to prevent tracking.)

Kentico provides an extensible model built around cookie levels, and your developers can custom fit your website to track and store exactly what you need. Find out more about the cookie levels and all the different Kentico cookies in our documentation.

Data protection

Tracking the visitors’ data and activities is essential to make your website and marketing efforts successful. Though you may feel lured to use every tracking tool possible and tailor the user experience based on what you learn about them, don’t forget about your responsibilities when it comes to tracking, storing, and working with the visitors' data. At least, your visitors must agree with the tracking, and you need to inform them about all the data you are collecting on your website.  Find out more how Kentico built-in functionality store personal data in Kentico documentation.

There are no boundaries on the Internet and different countries have different policies.  For example, you need to comply with the European Union's GDPR in the following cases:

  • Your company uses Kentico EMS and is based in the EU.
  • You provide products or services to customers based in the EU.
  • A company that provides you with services such as system administration, hosting, or help desk is based in the EU.

We strongly suggest that you consult with your lawyer about the exact wording of your consent declarations as well as relevant policies your website needs to comply with on the modern Internet.
title: How Kentico tracks visitors

You know why it's important to segment your audience. In this video I'll show you how you can do so by creating a contact group.

I want to be able to easily target all current and potential partners so I will create a contact group that includes all these people. I'll navigate to the Contact groups application and create a new contact group. I'll call it Partnership and include a short description of this group so that my colleagues know its purpose as well.

I'll add a condition to my contact group so that I don't have to manually check my contact database for those who have submitted the form expressing interest in becoming a partner.

Now I need to set up the condition so I'll search for "form". And I'll add this rule to the left column. I'll specify which form I have in mind and save everything.

Once I've saved the group, I can see a Rebuild contact group button, which checks my contact database to see if anyone meets the condition I've set up. When the contact list has been rebuilt, I can see all contacts in this group on my Contacts tab.

Several people have told me about their interest in my partnership program in person but haven't submitted the form and therefore weren't added with the condition, so I'll add them manually.

I've created two accounts for my partner cafes so I'll add them to this contact group as well.

When I navigate back to my Contacts tab, I can see all the contacts - those added because of the condition and those added manually.

I can now use this group to target my message to the right audience more effectively than before.

You've seen how easy it is to create and manage contact groups in Kentico, so try it yourself today!

body:
Contact groups are segments of existing contacts in your contact database. Contact groups help you divide your site visitors and users into groups that share same characteristics, such as age, location or activity. Using such a group, you can target your on-line marketing efforts more accurately.

Contacts as well as contact groups are global objects which means they are shared across all websites running within one Kentico instance.

There are two ways how a contact becomes a member of a contact group. You can assign contacts to groups manually (and create static contact groups). Or you define sets of conditions for condition-based (aka dynamic) contact groups, and let the system handle segmenting the contacts automatically. 

Kentico CMS licenses allow only static contact groups into which you manually add your contacts.
title: Static vs condition-based contact groups

body:
Segmenting your contacts will allow you to break up your database into smaller portions that you can target more effectively. Here are a few points you should consider when segmenting.

  1. Start with an up-to-date contact database. If you are working with outdated contacts, segmenting your audience won't help you.
  2. Define your reason for segmenting. What are you hoping to achieve at the end? Examples include segments focused on the customer journey.
  3. Don't create segments for everyone. There will be contacts who don't fit into any of your marketing efforts because you don't have enough information about them or resources to target them.
  4. Start small. You don't need to segment your whole contact database at once. Concentrate on your goals.
  5. Don't overdo it. It is easy to create too many segments. Being more generic will allow you to target a wider base.
  6. Use everything you know. Segment your contacts based on information they've provided you as well as data you've gathered about them.
  7. Target your segments with relevant content. Segmenting your audience helps you find the people who may be interested in the particular content you are sharing.
  8. Choose the right way to segment for your task. There are several ways of segmenting contacts in Kentico, so choose the one that best fits what you want to accomplish. Use accounts to target based on the company. Use contact groups to divide contacts into segments based on one or just a couple of characteristics. Use personas to define who your customers are.
  9. Analyze engagement. You want to know how people are responding to your efforts. Sometimes, the results won't match your expectations. In such cases, you'll need to refine your segments to reach the right people.
title: Best practices for segmenting your contacts

title: Introduction

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Why use lead scoring

So you've got a great website with hundreds or even thousands of visitors. That's great, except how do you know which ones are interested to you and your business? Some visitors came to you by accident, some are looking for something you offer, but are not ready to buy, some are already clued into what you're offering and these hot leads are ready to buy ... now! But how do you find these needles in your haystack? The solution is: lead scoring.

You can target your hottest leads first, closing the easiest sales. Then you can work down, focusing on instilling trust in those who need a little encouragement. To simplify this task, you filter out the poorest scorers, so as not to waste time on the wrong sort of visitor.

So how can lead scoring work for you? As your visitor browses your website, you can trace their actions and see what is watched, clicked, and downloaded and whether the visitor comes back to your website for more. For each of these activities, your visitor is assigned points and these inform you about how much they've learned about your offer so far. This information represents implicit data gathered automatically to tell your about your visitor's engagement with your business. You may also be provided with personal data, such as when the visitor submits a form to get more details about your offers.

You can then assign points based on the quality and relevance of the data provided. This information represents explicit data showing you how well the visitor fits your business. Examples of implicit data you gather might include the number of visited pages, the number of times the visitor returned to your website, which videos they watched, and what they downloaded. You choose which implicit data to collect based on what's important for your business. Examples of explicit data you gather might include the visitor's region, phone number, job title, and mailing address.

If you score each visitor with your own lead scoring rules, you can identify visitors who score well in terms of engagement AND fit to your business. And that's your hot lead. Your visitors are then grouped by score, with your hot leads in the top right group.

Within the overall score, the further right the group, the more engaged the leads are, the higher the group, the better they fit your business. Your hot leads are ready to buy, and so require a quick response right now. Those visitors scored as warm leads are undecided and need further nurturing from you. And visitors scored as cold leads can be ignored for the moment.

So you see, using lead scoring can save time and increase sales by helping you focus on where you can get the greatest returns.

body:
Visitors come to your website every day and do various things – they read your blog posts, get to know more about your company, and find out about your offers. Not everyone comes to your website ready to buy straight away. Sometimes they are just browsing and not searching for any particular information.

How can you distinguish where your visitors are in the nurturing process? For most companies, the majority of contacts will be at the start of the process, while the fewest will have completed it. Therefore, each company generally has a sales funnel to track and evaluate contacts within its sales processes. You can see an example of such a funnel below.

Prospects are people who have interacted with your brand in some way. They might have visited your website, heard about your company, or read some of your content on social media. You don't know much about each other. These represent the majority of your website visitors.

Contacts are people you've had an interaction with, such as an email exchange, sales demo, or a newsletter sign up.

Leads are looking for a solution to their problem and see your company as a possible candidate. You know that they possess characteristics you have identified in your customers and so are interested in them. By nurturing them and learning more about them and their requirements, you can prove your company provides a solution to their needs.

Finalists are fully qualified for your sales team. They are highly interested in your solution and know the price they are willing to pay. These are the people your sales team will negotiate with.

Clients are the final goal of funnel - paying customers.
title: Basics sales funnel

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
How to set up lead scoring

You know that lead scoring can help you focus your marketing and sales efforts to get great returns. In this video, I'm going to show you how to set up lead scoring in Kentico.

I'll go to my Scoring application and create a new score. I'll give it a name and then add in a description about finding people who are interested in partnering with us so our sales team can follow up and promote all the benefits of our partnership program. Since I want my sales team involved, I'll choose a score at which notifications will be sent and enter the sales team's email address to receive them. I'll save these settings and then go to my Rules tab to get started with the score.

I'll add a new rule to give a place for people to gain points. I'll start with just a basic rule about having people's emails, which has a small value for me. For this, I can stick with an Attribute, choose email

and give points if it's not empty. Then I'll save this rule.

I'll create another rule. This one I'll make about people considering a large purchase, which shows more interest in my business. I'll choose for this to be an Activity. Then I change the activity to putting something in their cart and choose as my most expensive product, which is targeted at businesses.

Then I can save the rule and move on to the next.

Now I want a rule about interest in wholesale partnership which is worth more points to me. People can express their interest through a specific part of a form, so I'll make this rule a macro and edit it. I'll add a rule about a specific field, choose the right form and field and then enter the text that shows their interest. And save the rule.

For my next rule, I remember that Sales has complained about not the leads in China they get not resulting in very many deals. So I'll take away some points for contacts in China. This can stay as an Attribute. I just need to select Country and then find China. Once I save my rule, I have everything I need.

I'm notified that my score isn't up to date, so I'll go back to an overview of my rules and recalculate the score to check which of my contacts match the rules I've set.

I'm not worried about my website being slowed down by this, so I'll do it now. Then if I go to my Contacts tab, I can see all of the contacts who have scores and even view the activities that led to those scores. My sales team will get emails about each of the high scorers who reached the threshold I set.

So that's how you can set up a score to find the most promising leads so you can follow up and nurture them along their journey.

title: How to set up lead scoring
displayTitle: How to set up lead scoring

body:
You know that keeping track of your leads can help you nurture them along their journey to making a purchase. Setting up a score for your leads helps you figure out where they are in your funnel. But how and where should you start? Below, you can find some best practices to help you.

  1. Determine whether lead scoring is right for you. Use lead scoring if you are getting a fair amount of leads, but many of them are not ready to purchase.
  2. Work together. Make sure your marketing and sales teams are on the same page. Lead scoring transcends both fields.
  3. Do your research. Start by analyzing your current customers and prospects. Find out what they have in common, what activities they've done on your website, and what you've found out about them from your interactions.
  4. Use the right data. You want to make sure to use only data that's relevant to your score. For example, when creating lead scoring in a B2B environment, some demographic data such as age may be unimportant.
  5. Consider demographics and behavioral data. What kind of people are the most interested - what are their ages, job titles, location? What is their level of interest - how far along their journeys are your prospects?
  6. Assign a negative score for undesirable actions or attributes. Do not be afraid to penalize leads for things that show a lack of interest/fit. These can include unsubscribing from newsletters, providing invalid email addresses, and non-fitting demographics.
  7. Give scores based on importance. Evaluate how important your conditions are and assign scores accordingly. You can start by dividing them into several categories, such as crucial, important, relevant, and negative. This will help you see relative values.
  8. Be open to re-evaluation. Your rules and point thresholds are not set in stone - you can change them based on results and feedback. You work in a dynamic and changing environment, so make sure your scores are also dynamic.
  9. Integrate your scores into your strategy. Lead scoring is not a stand-alone part of your marketing, but a part of your overall marketing and sales strategy.
  10. Be patient. Setting up lead scoring is a process, and it takes time.
title: Lead scoring best practices

You have defined an ideal segment of customers that would be a great fit for your campaign. To filter your contact base to a list of best-fit customers, you need to set some conditions your customers need to meet to get closer to the ideal. 

Based on your ideal target, the best fit are the most customers who visited the website recently, subscribed to email updates, and made a purchase. Customers who subscribed showed a serious interest in your products want to be kept in touch with company news, which means targeting this group is a no-brainer.

Finally, since it's the especially the US market where you have the best-by-far delivery system and market presence, customers coming from this region should be awarded some extra points just to make sure you don’t miss any opportunity to leverage your position on U.S. market.

The task:

Create a scoring group called “Hot leads” with the following rules:

  • Group name: “Hot leads” (code name: HotLeads)
  • Rules
    • Contact has purchased at least 1 product(s) in the last 30 days - 15 points
    • Contact is subscribed to MVC Dancing goat newsletter - 10 points
    • Contact comes from USA - 5 points
    • Contact has submitted form Coffee sample list in last 30 days - 15 points
